title: Does being cold make you sick?

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why people catch a cold or flu during late fall and winter?

options.label: A
options.text: The cold weather directly causes the viruses to spread.

options.label: B
options.text: People tend to stay indoors more often during the winter, which increases exposure opportunities for the pathogens to spread.

options.label: C
options.text: The humidity in the air increases during the winter, making it easier for viruses to spread.

options.label: D
options.text: The lack of sunlight during the winter weakens the immune system.

multiple-choice.question: Why does the lack of Vitamin D in the winter affect our health?

options.label: A
options.text: Because Vitamin D is a direct cause of the common cold.

options.label: B
options.text: Because Vitamin D is necessary for our immune system to function properly.

options.label: C
options.text: Because Vitamin D is not related to our immune system.

options.label: D
options.text: Because Vitamin D is only necessary for our skin health.

multiple-choice.question: What is the developing hypothesis behind the results of the study that put test subjects' feet into ice water?

options.label: A
options.text: That the cold temperatures cause the white blood cells to speed up their response to the virus.

options.label: B
options.text: That the cold temperatures cause blood vessel constriction, which slows the white blood cells from reaching the virus.

options.label: C
options.text: That the cold temperatures have no effect on the immune response.

options.label: D
options.text: That the cold temperatures increase the production of antibodies.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of the cold temperatures on the outer layer of the common cold virus?

options.label: A
options.text: It becomes softer and more fragile.

options.label: B
options.text: It becomes harder and acts like a shield.

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on the outer layer of the virus.

options.label: D
options.text: It causes the virus to mutate into a different form.

multiple-choice.question: Why are people more likely to catch a cold or flu during the winter?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the cold weather directly causes the viruses to spread.

options.label: B
options.text: Because people tend to stay indoors more often during the winter, which increases exposure opportunities for the pathogens to spread.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the humidity in the air increases during the winter, making it easier for viruses to spread.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the lack of sunlight during the winter weakens the immune system.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of mucus in our nose during the winter?

options.label: A
options.text: It acts as a protective barrier to pathogens.

options.label: B
options.text: It has no effect on the spread of viruses.

options.label: C
options.text: It increases the production of antibodies.

options.label: D
options.text: It causes the virus to mutate into a different form.

multiple-choice.question: Why do studies suggest that there is a correlation between cold weather and the common cold?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the cold weather directly causes the viruses to spread.

options.label: B
options.text: Because people tend to stay indoors more often during the winter, which increases exposure opportunities for the pathogens to spread.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the humidity in the air increases during the winter, making it easier for viruses to spread.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the lack of sunlight during the winter weakens the immune system.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of the cold temperatures on the immune response to the common cold virus?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases the production of antibodies.

options.label: B
options.text: It causes the white blood cells to speed up their response to the virus.

options.label: C
options.text: It slows the white blood cells from reaching the virus.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect on the immune response.

multiple-choice.question: Why do studies suggest that the common cold virus's outer layer becomes harder and acts like a shield during the winter?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the cold temperatures have no effect on the outer layer of the virus.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the cold temperatures cause the virus to mutate into a different form.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the cold temperatures cause the virus's outer layer to become harder and act like a shield.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the cold temperatures have no effect on the virus's outer layer.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it recommended to go outside more often during the winter, bundled up?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the cold weather has no effect on the spread of catching a cold.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the cold weather directly causes the viruses to spread.

options.label: C
options.text: Because people tend to stay indoors more often during the winter, which increases exposure opportunities for the pathogens to spread.

options.label: D
options.text: Because going outside more often during the winter can help to boost the immune system.

title: How short selling works

multiple-choice.question: What is a short position in investing?

options.label: A
options.text: A position where an investor buys a security today and sells it in the future hoping that the price will go up.

options.label: B
options.text: A position where an investor sells a security today and buys it back in the future hoping that the price will go down.

options.label: C
options.text: A position where an investor holds onto a security for a long time and sells it when the market is low.

options.label: D
options.text: A position where an investor buys a security and holds onto it forever.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between shorting and going long on a position?

options.label: A
options.text: Shorting involves buying a security and holding onto it for a long time, while going long involves selling a security and buying it back later.

options.label: B
options.text: Shorting involves selling a security today and buying it back in the future, while going long involves buying a security today and selling it later.

options.label: C
options.text: Shorting involves borrowing a security and selling it, while going long involves buying a security with cash.

options.label: D
options.text: Shorting involves buying a security with cash, while going long involves borrowing a security.

multiple-choice.question: What is a margin call?

options.label: A
options.text: A request from a broker to increase the amount of money in a margin account.

options.label: B
options.text: A request from a broker to decrease the amount of money in a margin account.

options.label: C
options.text: A request from a broker to sell a security in a margin account.

options.label: D
options.text: A request from a broker to buy a security in a margin account.

multiple-choice.question: What is a short squeeze?

options.label: A
options.text: A situation where a heavily shorted stock sees its price surge because investors who short sold the stock need to cover their position.

options.label: B
options.text: A situation where a heavily shorted stock sees its price drop because investors who short sold the stock need to cover their position.

options.label: C
options.text: A situation where a heavily shorted stock sees its price remain stable because investors who short sold the stock need to cover their position.

options.label: D
options.text: A situation where a heavily shorted stock sees its price increase because investors who short sold the stock do not need to cover their position.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main risk of short selling?

options.label: A
options.text: The risk of losing money if the stock price goes up.

options.label: B
options.text: The risk of losing money if the stock price goes down.

options.label: C
options.text: The risk of losing money and losing an infinite amount of money theoretically.

options.label: D
options.text: The risk of losing money and losing more money than what was initially invested.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference in the risk reward profile between long and short positions?

options.label: A
options.text: Long positions have a higher risk and higher reward, while short positions have a lower risk and lower reward.

options.label: B
options.text: Long positions have a lower risk and lower reward, while short positions have a higher risk and higher reward.

options.label: C
options.text: Long positions have a higher risk and lower reward, while short positions have a lower risk and higher reward.

options.label: D
options.text: Long positions have a lower risk and higher reward, while short positions have a higher risk and lower reward.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main disadvantage of short selling?

options.label: A
options.text: The risk of losing money if the stock price goes up.

options.label: B
options.text: The risk of losing money if the stock price goes down.

options.label: C
options.text: The risk of losing an infinite amount of money theoretically.

options.label: D
options.text: The risk of losing more money than what was initially invested and the risk of being forced to cover a position prematurely.

title: Why the ancient Greeks couldn't see blue

multiple-choice.question: Why was the word "blue" not mentioned in Homer's "The Iliad" and "The Odyssey"?

options.label: B
options.text: Because the ancient Greeks saw colors differently than we do.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the word "blue" did not exist in ancient Greek language.

options.label: D
options.text: Because Homer was describing things that were not blue.

multiple-choice.question: What is the order of colors that enter language in every culture?

options.label: A
options.text: Red, green, yellow, blue, black, white.

options.label: B
options.text: Black, white, red, green, yellow, blue.

options.label: C
options.text: Red, yellow, green, blue, black, white.

options.label: D
options.text: Blue, red, green, yellow, black, white.

multiple-choice.question: What is the evolutionary explanation for the order of colors in language?

options.label: A
options.text: Black and white are first because they are associated with danger.

options.label: B
options.text: Black and white are first because they help distinguish between night and day.

options.label: C
options.text: Red is first because it is associated with blood.

options.label: D
options.text: Green and yellow are first because they are associated with ripe and unripe foods.

multiple-choice.question: What is the second explanation for the order of colors in language?

options.label: A
options.text: The second explanation is that language trains our brain to see colors differently.

options.label: B
options.text: The second explanation is that the colors are associated with different emotions.

options.label: C
options.text: The second explanation is that the colors are associated with different objects.

options.label: D
options.text: The second explanation is that the colors are associated with different textures.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Himba people's perception of colors?

options.label: A
options.text: The Himba people see colors as distinct and separate.

options.label: B
options.text: The Himba people see colors as a continuum.

options.label: C
options.text: The Himba people have more words for types of green than we do in English.

options.label: D
options.text: The Himba people have fewer words for types of colors than we do in English.

multiple-choice.question: What is the example of how language trains our brain to see colors differently?

options.label: B
options.text: Seeing colors in a different light.

options.label: C
options.text: Noticing colors in a different context.

multiple-choice.question: What is the feedback loop in the brain that language trains our brain to see colors differently?

options.label: A
options.text: The feedback loop is the process of learning a new language.

options.label: B
options.text: The feedback loop is the process of noticing colors in a different context.

options.label: C
options.text: The feedback loop is the process of exaggerating the differences between colors.

options.label: D
options.text: The feedback loop is the process of contextualizing colors in a different way.

multiple-choice.question: What is the example of how language has an impact on brain function?

options.label: B
options.text: Noticing colors in a different context.

options.label: C
options.text: The brain's ability to create language.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between language and perception of the world?

options.label: A
options.text: Language creates our perception of the world.

options.label: B
options.text: Language influences our perception of the world.

options.label: C
options.text: Language has no impact on our perception of the world.

options.label: D
options.text: Language is a reflection of our perception of the world.

multiple-choice.question: What is the conclusion of the video?

options.label: A
options.text: Language trains our brain to see colors differently.

options.label: B
options.text: Language has an impact on brain function.

options.label: C
options.text: Language is a reflection of our perception of the world.

title: Why do we get goose bumps?

multiple-choice.question: What is the scientific term for the phenomenon of hair standing on end, also known as goosebumps?
What is the primary reason why we experience goosebumps when we're cold?

options.label: B
options.text: To create anticipation in the brain

options.label: C
options.text: To create a buffer between our skin and the cold air

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the tiny muscle at the base of every individual hair on the body?
What is the theory that suggests that sad songs are more likely to cause chills than happy songs?

options.label: B

options.label: B

title: What would happen if the world went vegetarian?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Domestic herds of animals would disappear, and vast quantities of land would be freed up.

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: They would all become wealthy and own multiple cars.

C: Domestic herds of animals would disappear, and vast quantities of land would be freed up.
